subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Wynn Resorts (WYNN) abandons talks to acquire Crown Resorts (CWN AT) after the latter's premature disclosure
content:
AUSTRALIA

Coca-Cola Amatil (CCL AT) - Co. is scouting for start-ups in Indonesia. (AFR)

Commonwealth Bank of Australia - Co. reduced interest rates on its fixed-rate loans for home owners and investors yesterday. (SMH)

Crown Resorts (CWN AT) - Wynn Resorts (WYNN) is said to finish all talks with the Co. regarding any transaction as executives were said to be angered by Crown publicly revealing the takeover discussions. (Newswires)

Flinders Mines (FMS AT) - Co. resolved to withdraw March 19th revised delisting application. (Newswires)

Michael Hill International (MHJ AT) - Co. Q3 rev. fell 0.8% Y/Y to AUD 118.5mln. (Newswires)

National Australia Bank (NAB AT) - New Zealand Fidelity Life is also said to be interested in Co.’s NZ life insurance business. (Newswires)

Wesfarmers (WES AT) - Co. is said to be looking at further acquisitions in the lithium market. (AFR)

                                                                                            

JAPAN

Aeon Mall (8905 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 33.5bln vs. Prev. JPY 30.5bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Japan Post Holdings (6178 JT) - Japan’s government is to reduce stake in the Co. to the legal minimum of just over 33% later this year to complete privatization process with the share sale seen to be valued at JPY 1.36tln. (Newswires)

J Front Retailing (3086 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 27.4bln vs. Prev. JPY 28.5bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT) - Co. announces initial executive investment team for USD 5bln Latin America technology growth fund. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Asiana Airline (020560 KS) - Private equity firms are speculated to be interested in the airliner. (Newswires)

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS) - Co. partners with Tencent (700 HK) for safety and entertainment in connected cars. (Nikkei)

LG Chem (051910 KS) - Co. raised USD 1.56bln via global debt sale to fund EV battery business. (Yonhap)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
GLOBAL

IMF cut its global growth forecast for 2019 to 3.3% from 3.5% and kept 2020 forecast unchanged at 3.6%, while it cut US growth forecast for 2019 to 2.3% from 2.5% but raised 2020 forecast to 1.9% from 1.8%. IMF cut Euro-Area 2019 growth forecast to 1.3% from 1.6% and lowered 2020 forecast to 1.5% from 1.7%, while it raised China 2019 growth forecast to 6.3% from 6.2% but cut 2020 growth forecast to 6.1% from 6.2%. (Newswires) 

ASIA-PAC

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he will conduct a call with US Trade Representative Lighthizer and China's Vice Premier Liu He later. In related news, China's Foreign Ministry Spokesman Lu said China and the US have made substantial progress in the latest trade talks, while there were also comments from US Agriculture Secretary Perdue that he spoke with China about reducing tariffs on US ethanol and suggested that things look positive. (Newswires)

Chinese State Council reiterated its view that the relevant authorities should enforce proper usage of interest rates and reserve requirements to expand credit and reduce lending costs. (Newswires)

China and EU leaders have agreed to issue a joint statement after a meeting in Brussels and Chinese Premier Li commented that they need to accelerate talks on EU-China investment treaty. Furthermore, EU's Tusk said talks with China have been tough but ultimately fruitful and there has been a breakthrough on subsidies, while EU's Juncker said they are working to remove barriers to market access and the aim with China is to agree an investment pact by the end of 2020. (Newswires) 

UK/EU

UK Lawmakers accepted PM May's plan to seek a Brexit delay through until June 30th (420 ayes vs. 110 noes). (Newswires)

EUs Tusk said that the June 30th is not long enough for a Brexit extensions and would rather propose an extension of up to a year with a flexible exit, while Tusk added that a long extension averts a rolling crisis and that there is little reason to believe that UK ratification would be done by June. (Newswires)

Draft EU statement noted that the EU are to agree to further Brexit delay, while it was also suggested that the UK is to act in a constructive and responsible manner throughout this unique period in accordance with the duty of sincere cooperation and if UK fails to live up to obligations, a withdrawal will occur on June 1st 2019. (Newswires/FT)

Downing Street spokesperson announced that the government and Labour Party have agreed to further talks on Thursday and that both sides are working hard to find a way forward. (Newswires)

A leading Brexiteer initially stated that they have been advised German Chancellor Merkel is willing to put a five-year time limit on the Northern Ireland backstop according to BBC's Watt, although Germany later denied the reports that Chancellor Merkel would be willing to accept a 5-year time limit to the backstop. (Newswires) Italy confirmed that it is to cut 2019 GDP growth target to 0.2% from 1.0% and stated there will be no new taxes. (Newswires)

Preparations have started for EU retaliation in Boeing (BA) WTO subsidies case, according to the European Commission. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

US API Weekly Crude Stocks +4.09M vs. Exp. +2.3M (Prev. +3.0M). (Newswires)

US EIA cut 2019 world oil demand forecast by 50k BPD to 1.4mln BPD YY increase and cut 2020 world oil demand growth by 10k BPD to 1.45mln BPD increase. EIA expects US crude output to rise in 2019 by 1.43mln BPD to 12.39mln BPD (prev. 1.35mln BPD rise) and sees US oil demand to rise by 360K BPD in 2019 (unchanged), while it expects US crude output to rise in 2020 by 710K BPD to 13.10mln BPD (prev. 730K BPD) and sees US oil demand to rise by 250K BPD in 2020 (prev. 220K BPD rise). (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak said there is no need to extend oil production deal if the market is forecast to be balanced in H and that a decision on oil deal will be made in June. (Newswires)

Two of Venezuela's four oil upgraders have restarted operations which will bring 298,000 bpd back online. In other news, Venezuela removed 8 tonnes of gold from its central bank last week and gold reserves have fallen by 30 tonnes since January which are now at 100 tonnes. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Senior Iranian Revolutionary Guard Commander has warned US aircraft carriers not to pass close to the Revolutionary Guards speed boats. (Newswires) 

US

US Senate Majority Leader McConnel has spoken to House Speaker Pelosi and US President Trump about a bipartisan two year deal on budget caps, while there were also comments from Treasury Secretary Mnuchin that President Trump is not interested in holding debt ceiling increase 'hostage' to secure border wall funding. (Newswires)

WTO ruling dismisses Canadian challenge against US tariffs on softwood lumber. (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

Boeing (BA) fell after reports emerged that the 737 grounding is costing USD 1bln per month. Apple (AAPL) shares were initially buoyed after Wedbush raised its price target, however the stock went on to snap a 10 day runs of gains with some suggestions of profit taking. Facebook (FB) shares traded higher after Morgan Stanley commented positively on Instagram monetising it’s Stories feature. Disney (DIS) and Cabot Oil & Gas Corp (COG) traded up after both receiving upgrades from Cowen & Co, who raised both firms’ ratings to ‘outperform’. US financials including, JP Morgan Chase (JPM), Wells Fargo & Co (WFC) and Bank of America Merrill Lynch (BAC) all traded lower after a story emerged suggesting US big banks will report weak investment banking fees. Pentair (PNR) shares fell after the water treatment company forecast full-year profits below expectations on the back of cold weather. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) snaps an 8-day win streak on reports of an M&A deal with Crown Resorts (CWLDY). Cerner Corp (CERN) posted its best daily gain in over 5 years after reports emerged of an agreement with activist investor Starboard involving a USD 1.2bln buyback plan. United States Steel Corp (X) shares plummeted after being downgraded to ‘underperform’ by Credit Suisse. SPX -0.6% at 2878, NDX -0.4% at 7568, DJI -0.7% at 26150.

Yields narrowed slightly along the curve in light trade ahead of Wednesday’s risk events (FOMC mins, Clarida speaks after market, ECB, Brexit conference). A soft NFIB survey resulted in some buying interest, and Trump’s Twitter trade war salvos also found buyers. The IMF lower growth expectations were also cited as a reason to buy. The Aramco offering of USD 12bln 5-parter didn’t dent the complex too much, despite books reportedly climbing over USD 100bln. The Treasury’s sale of USD 38bln of 3-year notes was ho hum; the auctioned tailed, and the yield was the lowest since Feb 2018. Direct participation rose sharply. Tomorrow the Treasury will auction 10-year notes; the last 10s auction stopped-through the screens, and saw the lowest yield at auction since Jan 2018; cover, meanwhile, was the highest since June, with dealers taking their lowest takedown since March 2017, leaving investment funds with a slightly higher takedown, while foreign participation was relatively unchanged. The latest positioning data indicated dealer holdings rose to a 5-week high in the latest data, to USD 13.89bln. Analysts at SocGen said that the sector appears cheap for the current auction cycle on asset swap vs the March auction cycle, and also says that the current 10 is cheap on the curve vs 5s and 30s. SocGen thinks the auction is likely to see a positive takedown. US T-note (M9) futures settled 6 ticks higher at 123-20+.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 9 April 2019: IMF downgrades growth forecast; US escalates trade tensions with EU
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

US MARKET WRAP 9 April 2019: IMF downgrades growth forecast; US escalates trade tensions with EU

 

* SNAP SHOT: Equities down, dollar flat, treasuries up, crude down.

* REAR VIEW: US looking to slap $11bln tariffs on EU; US small business optimism rises; IMF cuts global growth forecast.

* AHEAD: ECB; Fed Mins, US CPI; Brexit Summit; French, Italian & UK industrial Output; UK GDP; OPEC MOMR; Clarida aftermarket.

 

* TRADE: The US is mulling slapping $11bln of tariffs on imports of EU goods in retaliation for EU state subsidies to Airbus (AIR FP), which the WTO has judged are illegal and causes adverse effects to the US. The tariffs proposed are on passenger helicopters, wines, cheeses, ski-suits and certain motorcycles; additional tariffs on the EU’s power house auto sector are too being considered. The European Commission responded saying the tariffs are “greatly exaggerated”, and then reports followed through that the Commission had begun preparing retaliation tariffs in response; however the EU did say it was open to talks with the US in regard to the subsidies on Airbus. President Trump doubled down on the threats, where he tweeted that subsidies of Airbus had been damaging to the US. Away from the US, following meetings between Chinese and EU officials in Brussels, EU Council President Tusk said that the talks had been tough, but ultimately fruitful, and that a breakthrough on subsidies had been made. EU’s Juncker said that they are working to remove barriers to market access, with the aim being to agree an investment pact by the end of 2020; Chinese Premier Li said they need to accelerate talks on the pact.

* PREVIEW – FOMC MINUTES (MARCH MEETING): The meeting minutes will reveal the FOMC’s thinking behind moving to a neutral stance, and the central bank is likely to have judged rates should remain on hold. The FFR path was revised down at the meeting, and the FOMC lowered its growth view. Traders will be looking for more details on the balance sheet run-off. Elsewhere, there will be attention on any discussions, if any, that the Committee may have had on loosening policy. Click here for the full RANsquawk preview.

* PREVIEW – ECB RATE DECISION: Unanimous expectations look for the ECB to leave its three key rates unchanged. ECB are expected to maintain current guidance on rates, reinvestments, growth and inflation. President Draghi unlikely to offer much in the way of concrete details on TLTRO3 or tiered rates. Click here for the full RANsquawk preview.

* US NFIB: The March US small business optimism index rose by 0.1 points to 101.8. Wells Fargo Economics’ analysts highlight, “While the index has fallen from lofty highs of recent years, optimism remains elevated and businesses continue to report plans to expand.” Looking beneath the index, the consumer confidence component remained strong, whilst the amount of firms expecting the economy to improve stayed relatively unchanged at 10.8%, “however those reporting that now was a good time to expand increased to 22.6%.” Small business hiring plans increased at a more cautious rate which confirms Wells’ view of “a more moderate pace of hiring this year.” The bank also noted that both firms reporting a raise in selling prices and firms expecting to raise prices both dipped lower in March, “reflecting more modest price pressures in coming months.”

* BREXIT: The Lords late on Monday, and the HoC on Tuesday, passed a Bill requiring UK PM May to request an Article 50 extension if there is no deal, although the motion seems somewhat mitigated given May's request for an extension to be granted until 30 June. On Tuesday, reports suggested that the EU will grant the UK an Article 50 extension, though it may exact a high price for delaying Brexit, including UK to give up rights in future EU budget and trade talks, and additionally, it could force the UK into a no-deal Brexit if it seeks to cancel elections to European Parliament; there were also mixed reports that Germany would allow a 5-year time limit to the Irish backstop, though this was denied by Berlin. UK PM May and German Chancellor Merkel both discussed a Brexit extension to 30 June, at their meeting, and the two leaders agreed on need for an orderly Brexit; May also outlined plans to conclude Brexit at the Emergency Summit. Her counterpart Merkel was reportedly showing support for a flexible Brexit extension. Elsewhere, the UK solicitor general said he cannot be certain that an A50 extension to 22/May would give enough time to achieve a Brexit deal (NOTE: May has already requested an extension to 30 June). US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that the US is preparing for a hard Brexit as a “very realistic outcome.”

* IMF: The IMF cut its global growth forecast for 2019 to 3.3% from 3.5%, 2020 forecast unchanged at 3.6%. It cut its US growth forecast for 2019 to 2.3% from 2.5%, raised 2020 forecast to 1.9% from 1.8%. It cut its Euro-Area 2019 growth forecast to 1.35 from 1.6%. The IMF said that the Fed's patient approach is appropriate. It said that the German slowdown may require 'prompt' fiscal measures, and that the ECB should keep monetary policy as accommodative. Adding that the BoE should be 'cautious', and that a no-deal Brexit could hit UK & EU economies hard. IMF official said coordinated stimulus and synchronised fiscal stimulus might be needed if downside risks to global economy materialises

* EIA STEO: US EIA cuts 2019 world oil demand forecast by 50k BPD (to +1.4mln BPD YY), and also cut 2020 world oil demand growth by 10k BPD (to +1.45mln BPD YY) The EIA also expects US crude output to rise in 2019 by 1.43mln BPD (to 12.39mln BPD vs a previous 1.35mln BPD rise), and expects US crude output to rise in 2020 by 710K BPD to 13.10mln BPD (prev. +730K BPD). The EIA also thinks that US oil demand will rise by 360K BPD in 2019 (unchanged), and sees US demand rising by 250K BPD in 2020 (prev. 220K BPD rise).

* WTI (K9) SETTLED USD 0.42 LOWER AT USD 63.98/BBL; BRENT (M9) SETTLED USD 0.49 LOWER AT USD 70.61/BBL. After two green days, WTI and Brent both are red for the session ahead of weekly inventory data. Understanding moves in Brent has been fairly straightforward as of late: OPEC supply cut deal and geopolitical tensions are tightening the market, as reflected in Brent's rising backwardation. Sanctions on Venezuela and tensions in Libya add to the narrative of tightening supply (though the latter's production has not been impacted just yet). There is also Monday's news that the Trump administration are to designate Iran's Revolutionary Guard as a terrorist organisation, ramping up tensions further. The strength of WTI is a little more puzzling, ING says: while it can partly be explained by last week's closure of the Houston Shipping Channel (which contributed to a lumpy build in the weekly inventory data), ING is still somewhat surprised by the relative strength in WTI, particularly given that US crude oil inventories have remained stubbornly high for both total US commercial crude inventories and stocks in Cushing. Accordingly, the Brent/WTI arb has been in focus, and slightly narrowed today (vs Monday's levels around USD 6.50). It is worth keeping an eye on US oil exports in this week's inventory data. Further strength of WTI could weigh on exports; ING notes that US exports have already fallen from their weekly high of 3.6mln BPD in mid-February (a time when the WTI/Brent arb was around USD 10.00) to around 2.7mln BPD in last week's EIA report. Energy inventory expectations: Crude +2.3mln, Cushing -0.419mln, Distillate -1.3mln, Gasoline -2.0mln.

* SPX -0.6% at 2878, NDX -0.4% at 7568, DJI -0.7% at 26150. SECTORS: Energy -1.3%, Materials -0.8%, Industrials -1.4%, Communications -0.5%, Cons Discretionary -0.9%, Cons Staples -0.2%, Healthcare -0.4%, Financials -0.9%, Tech -0.5%, Telecoms +0.0%, Utilities +0.3%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) fell after reports emerged that the 737 grounding is costing USD 1bln per month. Apple (AAPL) shares were initially buoyed after Wedbush raised its price target, however the stock went on to snap a 10 day runs of gains with some suggestions of profit taking. Facebook (FB) shares traded higher after Morgan Stanley commented positively on Instagram monetising it’s Stories feature. Disney (DIS) and Cabot Oil & Gas Corp (COG) traded up after both receiving upgrades from Cowen & Co, who raised both firms’ ratings to ‘outperform’. US financials including, JP Morgan Chase (JPM), Wells Fargo & Co (WFC) and Bank of America Merrill Lynch (BAC) all traded lower after a story emerged suggesting US big banks will report weak investment banking fees. Pentair (PNR) shares fell after the water treatment company forecast full-year profits below expectations on the back of cold weather. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) snaps an 8-day win streak on reports of an M&A deal with Crown Resorts (CWLDY). Cerner Corp (CERN) posted its best daily gain in over 5 years after reports emerged of an agreement with activist investor Starboard involving a USD 1.2bln buyback plan. United States Steel Corp (X) shares plummeted after being downgraded to ‘underperform’ by Credit Suisse.

* US T-NOTE (M9) FUTURES SETTLE 6 TICKS HIGHER AT 123-20+. Yields narrowed slightly along the curve in light trade ahead of Wednesday’s risk events (FOMC mins, Clarida speaks after market, ECB, Brexit conference). A soft NFIB survey resulted in some buying interest, and Trump’s Twitter trade war salvos also found buyers. The IMF lower growth expectations were also cited as a reason to buy. The Aramco offering of USD 12bln 5-parter didn’t dent the complex too much, despite books reportedly climbing over USD 100bln. The Treasury’s sale of USD 38bln of 3-year notes was ho hum; the auctioned tailed, and the yield was the lowest since Feb 2018. Direct participation rose sharply. Tomorrow the Treasury will auction 10-year notes; the last 10s auction stopped-through the screens, and saw the lowest yield at auction since Jan 2018; cover, meanwhile, was the highest since June, with dealers taking their lowest takedown since March 2017, leaving investment funds with a slightly higher takedown, while foreign participation was relatively unchanged. The latest positioning data indicated dealer holdings rose to a 5-week high in the latest data, to USD 13.89bln. Analysts at SocGen said that the sector appears cheap for the current auction cycle on asset swap vs the March auction cycle, and also says that the current 10 is cheap on the curve vs 5s and 30s. SocGen thinks the auction is likely to see a positive takedown.

* FX WRAP: Newswires were attributing the USD weakness to heightened trade tensions (this time the US aiming at the EU), while the IMF cutting its global growth view did little to help. There was some positive points in the IMF report; while the US and European near-term growth view was cut, the IMF raised China growth forecast slightly, and talked about stability in the nation - as we have seen in recent PMI data for Feb and March. The DXY is sitting on the 97.00 figure (a new low for April) as we head into APAC trade, ahead of FOMC minutes on Wednesday, and before then, Fed's Clarida speaks overnight. Also in central bank activity, the ECB meeting on Wednesday will likely be a dull affair, and the EUR is sitting at unchanged levels as we end the US session. AUD watchers will be tuned in to comments from the RBA dep gov Debelle overnight, who will be speaking on the state of the economy. EMFX was mixed with the MXN and ZAR gaining, although RUB, NOK and CAD were weaker as oil fell, while importers (KRW, INR, TRY) were mixed with INR slightly firmer ahead of the start of elections on Thursday.

PREVIEW: US to sell USD 38bln in 3-year notes at 1800 BST/1300 EDT on 9 April 2019
content:
* WEEK'S SUPPLY: The US Treasury will this week auction USD 78bln in 3-year (USD 38bln, Tue), 10-year (USD 24bln, Wed) and 30-year (USD 16blnm Thu). With USD 77.8bln maturing at month-end settlement, the auctions will raise around USD 200mln in new cash, according to TD Securities. The bank adds that with USD 180mln maturing on the Fed's balance sheet, there will be nearly no add-ons at mid-month settlement. 

* RECENT AUCTIONS: Have generally performed well, with investors piling into havens at the beginning of the year amid the market uncertainty. While market pricing remains elevated (around 50% chance of a rate cut by the end of the year), it has backed off from extremes. TD Securities expects that, with the Fed's balance sheet run-off ending in October, the bank expects the Treasury to cut auction sizes in the 2-year to 3-year sector, which could support demand at the front-end. 

* 3-YEAR AUCTION: Cover was higher at the previous 3-year auction to the highest in 2019 (2.6x) even as yields declined in the run up to the auction. Final demand, however, was somewhat weak, Barclays notes, with dealers taking down marginally more supply than the first two auctions in the year. The prior auctions tailed by 0.4bps, which was wider than the recent average around 0.2bps. In terms of the upcoming auction, Barclays says the current 3-year note (the March 2022) is a potential deferred cheapest-to-date candidate in TUM0 and trades rich on the curve, similar to other deferred TU CTD securities (i.e., Dec21s, Sep21s, and Jun21s). As a result, Barclays estimates that the WI should trade at a liquidity discount to current 3s. "Furthermore, the quoted roll is biased higher due to the 0.6bps bad day adjustment in the WI; the bond matures on Good Friday (April 15, 2022), which is no settlement," adding that they believe that the WI roll is appropriately priced."

Daily FX Wrap: a degree of risk-off trade in the run up to ‘super Wednesday’
content:
JPY

The Yen is now in pole position within the major ranks amidst a gradual erosion of risk appetite due to a growing list of bearish impulses and factors, including heightened prospects of reciprocal US-EU trade tariffs, ongoing Brexit uncertainty and more IMF growth forecast downgrades. Moreover, the Fund delivered another warning that downside risks could materialise and warrant coordinated/synchronised stimulus, both monetary and fiscal, while major risk events looming tomorrow may also have prompted some safe-haven or defensive positioning. Usd/Jpy tripped stops through the 111.25-22 area and earlier intraday low around 111.24, with decent option expiries between 111.25-20 (1.8 bn) not providing much in the way of support on the way to and just through 111.00. Next in line for bears is 110.92 which is the 100 DMA and also close to a couple of other chart support levels. 

AUD/EUR

Vying for 2nd spot as the Aussie fades on the overall deterioration in sentiment tone after outperforming for the most part in wake of encouraging home loan stats overnight and another rise in iron ore prices alongside other commodities. Aud/Usd lost momentum just above 0.7150 and now looks set to end Tuesday’s EU session below a key Fib (0.7149) and the 100 DMA (0.7142). Similarly, the single currency drifted back from a marginal new recent high vs the Greenback, which coincided with Fib resistance at 1.1284, as the DXY managed to hold just above chart support at 96.806 within a 97.085-96.853 range, but remains underpinned having breached 1.1250 yesterday.

NZD/CHF/GBP/CAD

All narrowly mixed vs the Usd as the Kiwi slipped back below 0.6750 in sympathy with its Antipodean peer and the Aud/Nzd cross held towards the upper end of 1.0595-60 trading parameters. Meanwhile, the Franc meandered between 0.9998-81 with unchanged and as forecast Swiss jobless rates hardly registering, but Cable was considerably more choppy within a 1.3045-1.3121 band against the backdrop of yet more conflicting Brexit-related headlines, and especially reports about German Chancellor Merkel is willing to look at a 5 year limit to the Irish backstop that were subsequently denied. Finally, the Loonie lost momentum from sub-1.3000 vs its US rival as crude retreated from best levels and the WTO rejected Canada’s appeal against US softwood lumber levies.

EM

Some respite for the Try even though the ruling party refuses to give up on Istanbul and persists with efforts to overturn the electoral board’s ruling that a limited recount is appropriate. However, the Lira is still close to worst levels circa 5.6800 vs the Buck ahead of Wednesday’s Turkish Economic Plan that along with the ECB policy meeting, US CPI, EU emergency Brexit Summit and FOMC minutes forms part of what is being dubbed ‘super Wednesday’. Conversely, the Zar continues to outperform as the Rand got another ratings agency boost when S&P predicted that SA will push forward with structural reforms after elections and gave no inference that it is contemplating a cut to the outlook or credit standing. Usd/Zar inched closer to 14.0000 at 14.0100 before consolidating ahead of the round number.

9th April 2019

EARNINGS

  • Pentair (PNR) Q1 adj. EPS USD 0.43 vs. exp. USD 0.53, sales down 6% vs. last year. Cuts FY19 EPS and revenue view to below expectations. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – The iPhone maker has had its PT raised to USD 225 from USD 215 at Wedbush, where analyst David Ives maintains his Outperform rating, citing demand trends are turning around following recent price cuts. (Newswires)
  • Boeing (BA) – China has decided to send experts to the FAA panel review to evaluate the safety of 737 MAX jets; separately, China Aircraft Leasing Group has denied a SCMP story that claimed it had put an order for 100 of the jets on hold. Elsewhere, Carson Block’s Muddy Waters Research tweeted “And so USD BA has turned to blame the victim in the 2nd crash. Anything 2 protect the company. But let's be clear: But for MCAS malfunction, plane would have landed. That malfunction is almost certainly the result of putting SHORT-TERM profits above all else." (Newswires)
  • Boeing (BA), Airbus (AIR FP) – The US has proposed USD 11.2bln worth of tariffs as a countermeasure to the EU’s subsidies of Boeing competitor Airbus; Airbus has said it sees no legal basis for the measures. The proposed tariffs include fresh food products such as wine, cheese and seafood, along others. (Newswires)
  • Disney (DIS) – The entertainment conglomerate has been upgraded to Outperform at Cowen with a USD 131 PT, up from USD 102, where analyst Doug Creutz sees the co.’s “catalyst past for the next year as highly attractive.” Citi analyst Jason Bazinet has also raised his PT on the co. to USD 132 from USD 126. (Newswires)
  • Nike (NKE) – Attorney Michael Avenatti, who is claiming the sportswear co. bribes players to attend colleges, has said on CNBC that the co. pulled a stunt by having him arrested before he could go public with his claims. (CNBC)
  • Verizon (VZ) – The telecoms co.’s Yahoo unit has reached a settlement with users whose details were stolen in a data breach, where it will pay out USD 117.5mln. (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT) – The retailer has ramped up its use of automation/robots to scan store shelves to ensure “busy stores run more smoothly”. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Allergan (AGN) – Sources claim that the pharma co.’s Botox unit, which last year accounted for one fifth of Allergan’s revenue at USD 3.6bln, is facing pressure as competition grows larger in the space. (WSJ)
  • American Airlines (AAL) - The airline sees Q1 total revenue per available seat mile, or TRASM, at flat to +1.0% YY vs. flat to +2.0% previously, primarily due to the grounding of the Boeing (BA) 737 MAX jets. (Newswires)
  • Bank of America (BAC) – The bank is to raise its minimum wage for employees to USD 20 per hour over a two-year period, with the minimum wage initially raising to USD 17 on May 1st, and then continue to rise till it reaches USD 20 in 2021. (Newswires)
  • Bank of New York Mellon (BK) – The bank expects to incur higher technology-related costs in 2019 than 2018; the bank reports its Q1 earnings on April 17th. (Newswires)
  • Cerner (CERN) – The medtech co. has entered a collaboration agreement with activist investor Starboard Value, which includes a board refreshment plan, commitments to operating margin targets, a new finance and strategy committee, and an additional USD 1.2bln share repurchase programme, bringing the total to USD 1.5bln. (Newswires)
  • Principal Financial (PFG), Wells Fargo (WFC) – Principle is to acquire Wells Fargo’s Institutional Retirement & Trust unit in a USD 1.2bln cash and debt financed deal, with deal expected to be accretive to net income and non-GAAP operating earnings per diluted share in 2020. (Newswires)
  • TechnipFMC (FTI) – The oilfield construction co. has been awarded a “significant” Subsea contract by Total (FP FP) E&P in Brasil for the Lapa field. (Newswires)
  • Wells Fargo (WFC) – The bank’s businesses are likely to struggle whilst it searches for a new CEO, according to Keefe, Bruyette & Woods analyst Brian Kleinhanzl, WSJ reports. (WSJ)
  • Chipmakers (INTC, NVDA, AMD) - Goldman Sachs expects chip memory pricing to decline in H2 2019 due to weak supply/demand outlook and high levels of inventories; NAND chip margin expected to be impacted as industry margins may turn negative. (Newswires)

NASDAQ

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – The new Google Cloud CEO, Thomas Kurian, is reportedly using strategies similar to Oracle (ORCL) in order to improve its strategic position to face competitors Amazon (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT). (WSJ)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – The retailer has hired the former SpaceX executive, Rajeev Badyal, alongside several of his team members to lead the co.’s Project Kuiper, an effort to launch 3,236 satellites into space to augment internet speed. (CNBC)
  • Electronic Arts (EA) – SunTrust maintained its Buy rating and USD 107 PT on the videogame developer, where analyst Matthew Thornton cited recent survey data showed promising data for user spending patterns on its Apex Legends game. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media giant has had its PT raised to USD 195 from USD 190 at Morgan Stanley, where analyst Brian Nowak is optimistic on Instagram’s path into e-commerce, which he believes could add USD 4bln of ad revenue by 2021. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB), Alphabet (GOOGL) – The two tech giants are set to face Congress later this week, where they will both receive scrutiny over biases related to white nationalism and political bias on their platforms. (Washington Post)
  • Western Digital (WDC) – The chipmaker has had its PT raised to USD 60 from USD 55 at RBC Capital, where analyst Mitch Steves maintained his Outperform rating, citing his analysis of NAND memory fab assets point to upside of USD 12.50 per share. (Newswires)
  • Wynn Resorts (WYNN) – The casinos and resorts co. has entered preliminary acquisition talks for the Australia-based Crown Resorts, with an acquisition value of approximately USD 8bln, in a 50-50 cash and stock deal, where one Crown share will be exchanged for 0.042 Wynn shares. This comes after Wynn made a less favourable bid which was swiftly rejected. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 9th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Major European indices have traded choppily [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.2%], following on from the cautious trade overnight ahead of tomorrows risk events.
  • Brexit sentiment, along with sterling, was buoyed by reports of German support for a 5yr backstop time-limit; however, this was subsequently denied
  • On the trade front, USTR has released a list of EU products which may be subject to tariffs if the EU does not remove subsidies for Airbus
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Fed's Quarles & Clarida, Supply from the US

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets eventually turned mostly positive on what was a predominantly cautious session following a mixed performance on Wall St amid tentativeness ahead of upcoming earnings season and this week’s central bank activity including FOMC Minutes and ECB policy meeting. ASX 200 (U/C) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) were indecisive but with losses in Australia stemmed by strength in the energy sector as the escalating conflict in Libya lifted oil prices, while Tokyo sentiment mirrored a choppy currency. However, the region was not without its success stories as Crown Resorts surged over 20% after it announced it was in discussions regarding a takeover approach by Wynn Resorts and with Sony higher by more than 7% on news Third Point was building an activist stake in the Co. and called for a review on ownership of several divisions. Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were also tepid amid a lack of any firm drivers and as trade-related news quietened down, while the PBoC also continued to refrain from open market operations. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre amid an indecisive risk tone and as participants awaited a 5yr auction, as well as Saudi Aramco’s USD 10bln bond offering which was more than 7x oversubscribed. Prices later recovered off their lows as the 5yr JGB auction later proved to better than previous with an improvement seen across most metrics including a higher b/c and accepted prices.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7142 (Prev. 6.7201)

Chinese State Council reiterates its view that the relevant authorities should enforce proper usage of interest rates and reserve requirements to expand credit and reduce lending costs. (Newswires)

 

US

US Trade Representative Lighthizer released a list of EU products that could be subject to tariffs if the EU does not remove subsidies for Airbus (AIR FP) and said the US is seeking to place tariffs on USD 11bln of goods as a countermeasure. (Newswires) Following this, a European Commission source says that the level of action taken against Airbus (AIR FP) subsidies is 'greatly exaggerated'; suggest that the European Commission are making preparations for retaliation rights regarding the WTO dispute over Boeing (BA) and that the EU remains open to discussions with the US regarding aircraft subsidies. (Newswires)

US judge issued an injunction against President Trump administration's policy of returning asylum seekers to Mexico. (Newswires)

UK/EU

There were initially reports from a leading Brexiteer stating that they have been advised that German Chancellor Merkel is willing to put a five year time limit on the Northern Ireland backstop, according to BBC's Watt. However, this was subsequently denied by Germany. (Twitter/Newswires)

UK Parliament approved the legislation forcing PM May to delay Brexit and avoid a no-deal Brexit on April 12th which later received Royal Assent and was signed into law. (Newswires)

Reports suggesting that the 1922 Committee want UK PM May to stand down with immediate effect. (Telegraph/Twitter)

Furthermore, the EU is to set a high price for delaying Brexit including UK to give up rights in future EU budget and trade talks, while it will force the UK into a no-deal Brexit if it seeks to cancel election to European Parliament. (BuzzFeed/Newswires)

UK ministers are to resume Brexit discussions with opposition Labour Party today. (Newswires) Sources indicate that UK PM May had not accepted Labour’s demand for a customs union, however, there was a move towards altering the non-binding political declaration. (BBC) Subsequently UK Trade Secretary Fox reportedly tells Conservative lawmakers that a Customs Union would be the 'worst of both worlds', according to Telegraph's Swinford. (Twitter)

EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier says that the EU is ready to improve & amend the deceleration on future UK ties in hours/days. (Newswires)

EU officials suggest that no member of the EU 27 has put forward an argument for blocking a further extension to Article 50. (Newswires)

UK BRC Sales Like-For-Like (Mar) Y/Y -1.1% vs. Exp. -0.8% (Prev. -0.1%); largest decline since April 2018. (Newswires)

UK Barclaycard Consumer Spending (Mar) Y/Y 3.1% (Prev. 1.2%), while the report noted that 69% of consumers are not confident in the economy which is the highest since the survey began in 2014. (Newswires)

Italian economic outlook is set for approval by the Cabinet Tuesday PM, with Italian PM Conte to host government talks on the economic outlook prior to this., according to a Italian Official. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US State Department banned 16 Saudi nationals from entering the US due to role in Khashoggi murder. (Newswires)

Iran placed US Central Command on its terror list. (Newswires)

Iranian leader Khameni rejects Us blacklisting of Iranian Revolutionary Guards by the US. (Newswires)

Iranian President Rouhani says if US pressure continues, Iran will produce IR8 Advanced Centrifuges For reference, Centrifuge cylinders are used for the separation of Uranium and could produce fuel for nuclear weapons from natural Uranium. (Newswires) 

 

EQUITIES

Choppy trade for European equities thus far [EuroStoxx 50 +0.2%] following a cautious Asia-Pac session where China was tepid amid the lack of any firm drivers ahead of tomorrow’s risk-packed session. Analysts at HSBC believe that the Chinese economy has bottomed, and growth will pick-up in the coming months as the private sector feels the effects from corporate tax cuts. Over in Europe, stocks nursed some of the losses seen at the open after jitters from the US’ release of prelim tariffs on USD 11bln of EU products [Full list available on the headline feed] somewhat waned after sources noted that the legal actions taken against Airbus (-1.5%) subsidies are “greatly exaggerated”, and the EU remains open to dialogue with the US. Furthermore, upside in equities was initially exacerbated amid reports that German Chancellor Merkel is reportedly willing to put a 5yr time limit on the Northern Irish backstop, although equities shed some gains after this was dismissed, but remain in positive territory. Sectors are relatively mixed with no clear outperformer or laggard. In terms of individual stocks, Swiss heavyweight Novartis’ (-9.8% unadj.) Alcon unit (+5.2%) began its first trading day on the front foot and opened above the CHF 46.50-53.50 indicative range at CHF 55.00. Elsewhere, SAP (-2.1%) fell to the foot of the DAX in light of downgrades at HSBC and UBS. Finally, Italy’s Prysmian (-3.9%) extended on losses seen at the open following further failed commission tests.

FX

GBP - Sterling leapt towards the top of the G10 table amidst reports that German Chancellor Merkel may be open to a fixed backstop timeframe (5 years touted), which could appease some of those unwilling to back the WA, according to a Brexiteer. Cable cleared the 55 DMA (1.3096) and 1.3100 handle on its way to 1.3121 in response, while Eur/Gbp retreated to 0.8595 from 0.8627 at one stage before a denial by the German Government. Looking ahead, UK PM May’s is in Berlin to see her German counterpart and has a subsequent meeting with French President Macron before Wednesday’s emergency EU Summit. Meanwhile, talks between Tory Cabinet members and the Labour party are ongoing to try and strike a deal, and interim updates remain mixed.

AUD/NZD - The Aussie has extended gains to 0.7150 vs its US counterpart and 1.0600 against the Kiwi as commodities continue to rally and overnight data in the form of housing finance confounded expectations to the upside. Aud/Usd is now looking at bullish chart levels including the 100 DMA and a 50% Fib at 0.7142 and 0.7149 respectively to maintain momentum on a closing basis, with decent if not insurmountable option expiries between 0.7150-55 (circa 770 mn) also on the radar. Meanwhile, Nzd/Usd is trying to tag along and trying to breach 0.6750 ahead of offers said to be sitting at 0.6760.

JPY - Usd/Jpy has drifted down within a 111.57-24 range and into a relatively heavy expiry zone, as 1.8 bn runs off from 111.20-25 vs 1.7 bn at 111.35-40, with the Yen seeing some safe-haven demand due to renewed US/EU tit-for-tat tariff posturing. Chart-wise, 111.25 also represents the 10 DMA, while resistance ahead of the 112.00 big figure comes via a daily formation around 110.78.

EUR - The single currency has consolidated yesterday’s clearance of 1.1250 vs the Dollar and is eyeing 1.1280 as the DXY slips a bit further below 97.000 to test support at 96.806 amidst broad declines in Usd/major pairings. However, a thick cluster of option expiries may drag Eur/Usd back down given 5.8 bn rolling off between 1.1245-75, not to mention a further 3.1 bn lower down.

CAD/NOK - Both benefiting from the ongoing strength in oil prices, and the latter to the extent that a knee-jerk spike in Eur/Nok in wake of weak Norwegian GDP data has already been reversed, with the cross currently straddling 9.6200 vs a high just shy of 9.6500. Meanwhile, the Loonie is pivoting 1.3300 vs its US counterpart and just eclipsed its previous April high.

EM - More thrills and spills for the Lira, as an initial rebound made on a reduced recount in Istanbul was thwarted by another rejection of the electoral board’s decision by the AKP that is insisting on a full election rerun. Usd/Try back up near 5.6700 vs 5.6425 and 5.6949 at the extremes.

FIXED INCOME

Volatile trade in EU debt after the relatively slow price action seen earlier, as Bunds led advances to fresh intraday highs amidst more EU angst over US tariff threats and then Gilts took over the reins with a swift pull-back on positive sounding Brexit reports before a snap-back on the denial. The 10 year benchmarks have settled down again more recently with Bunds back around par within a 165.11-54 range and Gilts only just a few ticks off-side between 128.27-127.82 parameters after a solid 2028 DMO tap. However, USTs have been more steady and underpinned with the curve fractionally flatter ahead of 3 year supply and as books swell for the multi-tranche ARAMCO offering, with demand said to be particularly strong for the longer maturities.

COMMODITIES

Another day of gains in the energy complex with WTI and Brent futures trading in proximity to USD 64.50/bbl and USD 71.00/bbl respectively; although the complex is trading towards the bottom of the days range. Developments in Libya remain a key factor in the upside seen recently with analysts at TD noting that “military tensions in Tripoli, Iranian sanctions and difficulties in Venezuela may cause deficits as OPEC+ is reducing supply and US shale activity is flattening — USD 68/bbl WTI in the cards”. That said, analysts at Goldman Sachs, due to lower projected inventories, expect further backwardation and modest upside in oil prices whilst forecasting the WTI/Brent spread to tighten to USD 4.50/bbl from Q4 2019 onwards. GS also raised its Q2 2019 Brent forecast to USD 72.50/bbl (Prev. USD 65.00/bbl) and maintained its USD 60.00/bbl 2020 forecast. Meanwhile, Russian Energy Minister Novak stated that there is no need to extend the OPEC+ output deal if the market is forecast to be balanced by H2, which his Saudi counterpart previously said was only 70-80mln barrel away. Elsewhere, metals are benefitting from the recent pullback in the Buck, with gold also profiting from recent flows into the yellow metal ahead of tomorrow’s risk-filled day. Copper gained amid continued strength in Chinese commodity prices in which Dalian iron ore futures gained for a 7th consecutive session amid tightening supply. Finally, Platinum caught a bid as markets speculate the impact of labour strikes in South Africa, which saw the metal break through key resistance levels whilst also triggering CTA short covering, according to TD.

Russian Energy Minister Novak says there is no need to extend oil production deal if the market is forecast to be balanced in H2, adds that a decision on oil deal will be made in June. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs expects further backwardation and modest upside in the energy complex due to lower projected inventories. Q2 2019 forecast raised to USD 72.50/bbl (Prev. USD 65.00/bbl) and maintains its USD 60.00/bbl 2020 forecast. (Newswires)

Equatorial Guinea crude oil output currently stands at 120k BPD, according to the country's oil minister. (Newswires)

Shell (RDSA LN) report that the strike at their Pernis refinery has had a ‘significant’ impact, the refinery has a capacity of around 400k BPD. (Newswires)

Indian refiners are holding back from purchasing Iranian oil loading in May as they await further clarity on potential further oil waivers. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

9th April 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets eventually turned mostly positive on what was a predominantly cautious session following a mixed performance on Wall St amid tentativeness ahead of upcoming earnings season and this week’s central bank activity including FOMC Minutes and ECB policy meeting. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) were indecisive but with losses in Australia stemmed by strength in the energy sector as the escalating conflict in Libya lifted oil prices, while Tokyo sentiment mirrored a choppy currency. However, the region was not without its success stories as Crown Resorts surged over 20% after it announced it was in discussions regarding a takeover approach by Wynn Resorts and with Sony higher by more than 7% on news Third Point was building an activist stake in the Co. and called for a review on ownership of several divisions. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were also tepid amid a lack of any firm drivers and as trade-related news quietened down, while the PBoC also continued to refrain from open market operations.

TRADE

European equities - US Trade Representative released a prelim list of EU products that could be subject to tariffs if the EU does not remove subsidies for Airbus (AIR FP) and said that US is seeking to place tariffs on USD 11bln of goods as a countermeasure. Potential tariffs could be imposed on new passenger helicopters, various cheeses and wines, ski-suits and certain motorcycles. [Full prelim list available on the RANsquawk headline feed]

FTSE

Standard Chartered (STAN LN) – Co. is reportedly expected to pay just above USD 1bln to settle a US regulatory investigations into breaches of sanctions against Iran and financial crimes control. (The Times)

GlaxoSmithKline (GSK LN) – Co’s two-drug treatment for HIV, ‘Dovato’, has received FDA approval. For reference HIV treatments are usually complied of three drugs. (FT)

BAE Systems (BA/ LN)/Rolls Royce (RR/ LN) – Reaction Engines has announced the successfully testing of its pre-cooling technology. Reaction Engines has received investment from the aforementioned Co’s and Boeing (BA). (FT)

British American Tobacco (BATS LN) – Co’s board has instructed head-hunters to seek a successor for Chairman Burrows, as he is to step down within the next few months. (Sky)

Centrica (CNA LN) – Co’s CEO received a 44% pay increase for FY18, in spite of the Co. imposing 2 bill increases a profit warning and altering over thousands of job cuts. (Guardian/BBC)

WPP (WPP LN) – EQT are reported to have interest in purchasing the Co’s Kantar unit for up to GBP 3.5bln. Previously been reported that the unit has interest from Apollo and Carlyle. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

HAYS (HAS LN) DOWNGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

PENNON GROUP (PNN LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

SEVERN TRENT (SVT LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGTH AT JP MORGAN CHASE

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Reports indicate that the trading unit is a key component for the ECB regarding merger talks with Commerzbank (CBK GY) and that regulatory approval will likely be dependent on measures laid out to improve profitability. (Newswires)

Fresenius (FRE GY) – CFO said Co. was looking into smaller or mid-sized acquisition this year and a larger takeover will rather come next year or later. (FAZ)

ZALANDO (ZAL GY) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT LIBERIUM CAPITAL

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

PAN EUROPE

Repsol (REP SM) – Co. proposes two share capital increases of par value of EUR 1 each, implementation and date not decided yet. Co. also proposes reduction in share capital via cancellation of Co. shares. (Newswires)

RANDSTAD (RAND NA) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

SMI

Novartis (NOVN SW) – Co. plans to pay a strong and growing annual dividend from the CHF 2.85/shr paid in June with no adjustments for the Alcon spin-off. Share buyback of up to USD 5bln announced in June is expected to be completed this year. Furthermore, Co’s CEO is targeting the limitation of merger and acquisition spending to around 5% of market cap. (Newswires/FT)

Nestle (NESN SW) – Co’s sale of Herta lunch-meat business could attract interest from Cargill and Smithfield Foods; according to source. Co. is working with an adviser to divest its hot dog brand which could be valued between USD 0.8-1.0bln, the sources said. (Newswires)

Givaudan (GIVN SW) – Q1 sales +6.3% LFL to CHF 1.525bln vs Exp. 1.500bln. Co. aims to outpace market with 4-5% sales growth and FCF of 12-17% of sales over a 5yr period. Co. intends to keep currency dividend policy and seeks to create value via targeted acquisitions.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 9th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian indices edged into positive territory, following a mixed performance on Wall St. and ahead of tomorrow’s risk events including ECB rate decision & FOMC minutes
  • Legislation avoiding no-deal and forcing an extension to Brexit has been written into UK law, while the EU want a 9/12-month extension if no agreement is reached by Friday
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US NFIB Business Optimism, Fed's Quarles & Clarida, Supply from Japan, UK & US

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets eventually turned mostly positive on what was a predominantly cautious session following a mixed performance on Wall St amid tentativeness ahead of upcoming earnings season and this week’s central bank activity including FOMC Minutes and ECB policy meeting. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) were indecisive but with losses in Australia stemmed by strength in the energy sector as the escalating conflict in Libya lifted oil prices, while Tokyo sentiment mirrored a choppy currency. However, the region was not without its success stories as Crown Resorts surged over 20% after it announced it was in discussions regarding a takeover approach by Wynn Resorts and with Sony higher by more than 7% on news Third Point was building an activist stake in the Co. and called for a review on ownership of several divisions. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were also tepid amid a lack of any firm drivers and as trade-related news quietened down, while the PBoC also continued to refrain from open market operations. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre amid an indecisive risk tone and as participants awaited a 5yr auction, as well as Saudi Aramco’s USD 10bln bond offering which was more than 7x oversubscribed. Prices later recovered off their lows as the 5yr JGB auction later proved to better than previous with an improvement seen across most metrics including a higher b/c and accepted prices.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7142 (Prev. 6.7201)

UK/EU

UK Parliament approved the legislation forcing PM May to delay Brexit and avoid a no-deal Brexit on April 12th which later received Royal Assent and was signed into law. (Newswires)

UK PM May is reportedly considering giving MPs a free vote on whether to hold a second referendum, although reports also noted that the Brexit Chief Whip is confident the government has the numbers to defeat any vote on a second referendum. Elsewhere, UK PM May has been warned by some members of the 1922 executive that a customs union is unacceptable, according to BBC’s Nick Eardley with separate reports suggesting that the 1922 Committee want May to stand down with immediate effect. (Telegraph/Twitter)

EU wants UK to approve Brexit deal this week or face a long delay and are to consider 9-month (also suggested by a rumour in the Telegraph) or 12-month extension if a withdrawal deal isn't approved by Friday, while the reports noted the EU want to be able to end the extension period if a new Brexiteer PM tries to cause problems during a long extension. Furthermore, the EU is to set a high price for delaying Brexit including UK to give up rights in future EU budget and trade talks, while it will force the UK into a no-deal Brexit if it seeks to cancel election to European Parliament. (BuzzFeed/Newswires)

UK Conservative party spokesperson said it remains the government’s intention to ratify a deal that allows a Brexit before 23 May 2019, so that the UK does not need to participate in European elections. However, it was also reported that the Cabinet Office confirmed the government laid a Day of Poll Order needed for Euro elections and stated they have taken the necessary steps required by law should the UK have to participate. (Newswires/Twitter)

UK ministers are to resume Brexit discussions with opposition Labour Party today, while there were earlier comments from Labour leader Corbyn that the government does not seem to be moving from red lines and so far Labour has not seen the commitments it wanted to see. (Newswires) Sources indicate that UK PM May had not accepted Labour’s demand for a customs union, however, there was a move towards altering the non-binding political declaration. (BBC)

Sources suggest the most likely outcome of Wednesday's emergency Brexit summit is an extension of the Brexit deadline to the end of May, according to ITV’s Peston. (Twitter)

UK BRC Sales Like-For-Like (Mar) Y/Y -1.1% vs. Exp. -0.8% (Prev. -0.1%); largest decline since April 2018. (Newswires)

UK Barclaycard Consumer Spending (Mar) Y/Y 3.1% (Prev. 1.2%), while the report noted that 69% of consumers are not confident in the economy which is the highest since the survey began in 2014. (Newswires)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer released a list of EU products that could be subject to tariffs if the EU does not remove subsidies for Airbus (AIR FP) and said the US is seeking to place tariffs on USD 11bln of goods as a countermeasure. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the DXY remained softer and tested the 97.00 level to the downside as its major counterparts held on to the prior day’s gains, with EUR/USD in the midst of a cluster of option expiries between 1.1250-1.1275 with a total value of over EUR 4.5bln which are set to expire at today’s New York cut and with GBP/USD mildly underpinned after both Houses of Parliament approved the Withdrawal Bill to extend Article 50 and avert the UK crashing out without a deal on April 12th. Looking ahead, UK ministers are to resume Brexit discussions with the opposition Labour Party today in attempt to solve the deadlock although the opposition party has suggested that the government has been unwilling to budge in talks so far, while the EU want the UK to approve the Brexit deal this week or face a long delay and will consider a 9-month or 12-month extension if a withdrawal deal isn't approved by Friday. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were choppy amid the indecisive risk tone, while better than expected Australian Home Loans and recent strength in commodities provided a base for antipodean currencies.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were positive with energy price remaining firm near fresh 5-month highs above the USD 64.00/bbl level on supply side risks mostly due to the escalation in Libya which also increases risks to supply from the country’s largest El-Sharara oil field which has a capacity of 315k bpd. Some have also suggested ongoing tensions with Iran and potential Saudi resentment after the US banned 16 Saudi nations from entering the US for involvement in the Khashoggi killing, were among other factors adding to the bias upside for oil. Elsewhere, gold prices only marginally benefited from a weaker greenback, while copper gained amid continued strength in Chinese commodity prices in which Dalian iron ore futures gained for a 7th consecutive session amid tightening supply.

 

GEOPOLITICS

Eastern Libyan forces confirmed they conducted airstrikes on Tripoli's Mitiga airport. (Newswires)

US State Department banned 16 Saudi nationals from entering the US due to role in Khashoggi murder. (Newswires)

Iran placed US Central Command on its terror list. (Newswires) 

US

US Treasury yields rose by 1.5bps-2bps at settlement. However, the day started off with a bid, and weak German data lent support. However, over the course of the session, the complex gradually eased, with some citing chunky supply this week out of the US Treasury, as well as the corporate slate (books on Aramco's USD 10bln M&A bonds are said to be above USD 60bln). Lower volatility in equities and generally stable S&P also left little need for the haven, while some also cited increased chatter about the reflation trade, too. Some suggest that the rate cut pricing in Fed funds might be a function of the Fed's independence under threat (Board nominee Moore has called for rate cuts recently, as has NEC director Kudlow), however, with optimism that a US/China trade deal can help boost global growth, and stabilising metrics in China too (which can feed through into Europe), there are certainly questions about the need for immediately looser policy. Ahead of FOMC minutes this week, money markets price under 50% chance of a rate cut in 2019 (vs over 50% at the end of last week). Major curve spreads were mixed at settlement. US T-note futures (M9) settled 4+ ticks lower at 123-14+.

US judge issued an injunction against President Trump administration's policy of returning asylum seekers to Mexico. (Newswires)
